NURSING NOTE 
     - 

    Has there been a FALL in the past 48 hours? 
         No
PATIENT EDUCATION
   BARRIERS TO LEARNING
   Patient:  No observed barriers to learning 
   Comments: 
   Family/Significant Other:  No observed barriers to learning
   Comments: 
   Information Taught: 
   To Whom: Patient, Significant Other
 
   Method:  verbal, handout, audiovisual 
 
   Learner Response:  Indicates Understanding 
 
   Comments: 
MORSE FALL SCALE
 
   History of Falls   0 No
   Secondary Dx      15 Yes
   Ambulatory Aid     0 None/ Bedrest/ Nurse assist
   IV/Hep Lock        0 No
   Gait/Transfer      0 Normal/BR/Wheelchair
   Mental Status      0 Oriented to own ability

   TOTAL SCORE:      15

BASIC PAIN ASSESSMENT/REASSESSMENT
Feb 22,2013
   WILDCATS - all areas MUST be completed for any reports of pain
      Patient Words Describing pain or Pain Behaviors Observed:
         no pain
      Intensity (0 no pain 10 worst possible) 0 

 
 Braden Scale for Predicting Pressure Ulcer Risk
 
 Date Given: 02/22/2013
 Clinician: Avivauser,Seven
 Location: Psychiatry
 
 Veteran: Avivapatient, Six
 SSN: xxx-xx-0926
 DOB: Feb 2,1957 (56)
 Gender: Female
 
   Braden Scale Score: 23
 
 Severe risk:  9 or lower.
 High risk: 10-12.
 Moderate risk: 13-14.
 Mild risk: 15-18.
 
 Questions and Answers
 
 Sensory perception -- ability to respond meaningfully to pressure-related 
discomfort
     No impairment.
 Moisture -- degree to which skin is exposed to moisture
     Rarely moist.
 Activity -- ability to change and control body position
     Walks frequently.
 Mobility -- ability to change and control body position
     No limitation.
 Nutrition -- usual food intake patterns
     Excellent.
 Friction and shear
     No apparent problem.
 
 Information contained in this note is based on a self report assessment and is 
not sufficient to use alone for diagnostic purposes. Assessment results should 
be verified for accuracy and used in conjunction with other diagnostic 
activities. 
 Copyright Barbara Braden & Nancy Bergstrom, 1988 

VITAL SIGNS:
            B/P:  122/72 (02/22/2013 08:00)
          Pulse:  78 (02/22/2013 08:00)
    Temperature:  98.3 F [36.8 C] (02/22/2013 08:00)
   Respirations:  14 (02/22/2013 08:00)
         Weight:  241 lb [109.5 kg] (11/20/2012 16:31)
         Height:  64 in [162.6 cm] (11/20/2012 16:31)
            BMI:  41
           Pain:  0 (02/22/2013 08:00)


Comments:
The pt is feeling much better today.  She slept for 6 hours, then woke up for a 
couple hourse, then slept for another 90 minutes.  This is a great improvement 
for her.  She seems much more up-beat and hopeful.  She says her mood is much 
improved and she hasn't had any suicidal thoughts since yesterday.  She would 
like to be discharged sometime in the next couple days if the doctor agrees.
text.author: AVIVAUSER,SEVEN
